occurrences.line_text: The royall virgin shooke off drowsy-hed,
His grated teeth for great disdeigne, and shooke
With that he stiffely shooke his steelehead dart:
That with the noise it shooke, as it would fall:
And shiuering speare in bloudie field first shooke,
And in his clownish hand a sharp bore speare he shooke.
He stearnly shooke, and therewith fierce did stryke
Full dreadfully he shooke that all did quake,
For euer when the Squire his iauelin shooke,
Who well perceiuing, how her wand she shooke,
His horses backe, yet to and fro long shooke,
And gnasht his teeth, and his head at him shooke,
And her long taile and fethers strongly shooke,
With trembling ioynts, as he for terrour shooke;
He shooke off luskishnesse, and courage chill
Rent by the root; which he so sternely shooke,
Did shine with siluer, and shoot forth his beame.
And through the persant aire shoote forth their azure streames.
So many learned impes, that shoote abrode,
And shooting in the earth, casts vp a mount of clay.
Shooting forth farre away two flaming streames,
And broke their bowes, and did their shooting marre,
And here and there shooting forth siluer streames,
To call backe life to her forsaken shop;
Of her intent, this further purpose to him shope.
Their scepters stretcht from East to Westerne shore,
By muddy shore of broad seuen-mouthed Nile,
The rolling billowes beat the ragged shore,
But since now safe ye seised haue the shore,
As weather-beaten ship arriu'd on happie shore.
Such as Diana by the sandie shore
A long the shore, as swift as glaunce of eye,
The little barke vnto the shore to draw,
Turnd to the shore, where that same warlike Lord
And that gay paire issuing on the shore
Himselfe appease, and issewd forth on shore:
Vpon that shore he spied Atin stand,
Lo, to that shore one in an auncient gowne,
Then pittie, he in hast approched to the shore.
They made the further shore resounden wide:
And spred his empire to the vtmost shore,
The whiles with bloud they all the shore did staine,
Bidding them nigher draw vnto the shore;
A seemely Maiden, sitting by the shore,
Stretch her white rod ouer the Belgicke shore,
And sitting downe vpon the rocky shore,
Till sadly soucing on the sandie shore,
So fell proud Marinell vpon the pretious shore.
Shortly vpon that shore there heaped was,
Along the margent of the fomy shore,
Stoutly forth stepping on the further shore,
Foolish Narcisse, that likes the watry shore,
And now she gan approch to the sea shore,
As she arriued on the roring shore,
And after cast him vp, vpon the shore;
And built Nausicle by the Pontick shore,
From shore to shore, emongst the Lybicke sands,
From shore to shore, emongst the Lybicke sands,
They which from shore behold the dreadfull sight
With whom as he did passe by the sea shore,
Where I by chaunce then wandring on the shore,
But vsd to fish for fooles on the dry shore,
From th'vtmost brinke of the Armericke shore,
To the sea shore he gan his way apply,
But when as nigh vnto the shore they drew,
Though darts from shore and stones they at him threw;
Did win the shore, whence he them chast away,
Meant them to haue incountred, ere they left the shore.
Giue leaue awhyle, good father, in this shore
Like as the wounded Whale to shore flies fro[m] the maine.
From wandring Stygian shores, where it doth endlesse moue.
From Stygian shores, where late it wandered;
For all the shores, which to the sea accoste,
Is not short paine well borne, that brings long ease,
So in short space they did to health restore
That short reuenge the man may ouertake,
That in short space he has them qualifyde,
Neither vnseemely short, nor yet exceeding long.
Nath'lesse the same enioyed but short happy howre:
And some like vgly Vrchins thicke and short:
That but if she did lend her short reliefe,
That in short space their foes they haue quite terrifide.
Short end of sorrowes they thereby did find;
And my short blisse maligne, yet mote they well
And welled goodly forth, that in short space
Her gentle speach applide, that in short space
To tucke about her short, when she did ryde,
Of broken bowes and arrowes shiuered short,
And much vnlike, th'one long, the other short,
She in short space did often bring to nought
And eke so short, that seemd their ends out shortly came.
That in short time his face they ouergrew,
That in short space his hurts he had redrest,
That his departure thence should be so short,
That in short space his wonted chearefull hew
Which was short tucked for light motion
Vppon the childe, but somewhat short did fall,
That in short space, whiles there with her he stayd,
In which her cursed tongue full sharpe and short
They fall too short of our fraile reckonings,
That in short space their malady was ceast,
Ne may a man prolong, nor shorten it;
Which is of them the shortest, as I see,
Shortly therein so perfect he became,
And shortly backe returne vnto this place,
The which he shortly did, and Vna left to mourne.
Nathlesse he shortly shall againe be tryde,
That shall I shortly purchase to your hond:
And shortly ouertooke: I breathing yre,
Yet shortly gaynd, that losse exceeded farre:
Doe flocke, awaiting shortly to obtaine
Thereof deuising shortly to be wroke,
Thence forward he him led, and shortly brought
That shortly he forgot the ieopardie,
But fierce Cundah gan shortly to enuie
And shortly brought to ciuill gouernaunce,
Who shortly it to him restord againe,
Yet shortly he renounst the vassalage
This good king shortly without issew dide,
But shortly was by Coyll in battell slaine:
Of these a mightie people shortly grew,
That th'vtmost sandy breach they shortly fetch,
That they it past, and shortly gan descry
Thence passing forth, they shortly do arriue,
And shortly grew to so great quantitie,
That shortly brent into extreme desire,
Supper was shortly dight and downe they sat,
Shortly they reard out of her frosen swownd;
Her shortly answered; Faire martiall Mayd
She shortly like a pyned ghost became,
Thou her afford, full shortly I her dead shall see.
That it shall make him shake, and shortly learne to fall.
Will bring, and shortly make you a mayd Martiall.
She shortly thus; Fly they, that need to fly;
Shortly vpon that shore there heaped was,
That shortly he a great Lord did appeare,
That shortly he from daunger was releast,
Shortly she came, whereas that woefull Squire
They wondred much, and shortly vnderstood,
That shortly she his dolour hath redrest,
That in her pregnant flesh they shortly fructifide.
Shortly vnto the wastefull woods she came,
And shortly asked her, what cause her brought
And shortly grew into outrageous fire;
And passing speede, that shortly he her ouerhent.
Will shortly yeeld it selfe, and will be made
Nought wants but time and place, which shortly shee
But soone he shall be found, and shortly doen be ded.
That shortly she Malbecco has forgot,
But Scudamour was shortly well aware
His siluer Harpe in hand, and shortly friends them make.
And eke so short, that seemd their ends out shortly came.
And cared not to spare, that should be shortly spent.
But shortly was likewise seene lying on the plaine.
And thought in mind it shortly to amend:
That seem'd to dust he shortly would it driue:
Her dearest loue full loth so shortly to forsake.
(Whereof it hight) and hauing shortly tride
He would her shortly leaue, and former loue forget.
That shortly them compelled to retrate,
And to the place of perill shortly came.
And by good fortune shortly him vnseated.
That she her loue to him would shortly gaine:
Began to spring which shortly grew full great,
I shortly will to you rehearse the same,
But the false mayden shortly turn'd againe
That shortly did all other beasts subdew.
Who shortly must repent that now so vainely brauest.
So that he shortly forst him to forsake
That through the wound his spirit shortly did depart.
The meede whereof shall shortly be thy shame,
The damzell was attacht, and shortly brought
In which an altar shortly they erected,
For they for better hyre did shortly looke,
Where shortly they in great acquaintance grew,
Shot many a dart at me with fiers intent,
The mortall sting his angry needle shot
Besides he feard her wrath, and threatned shot
For Guyons lookes, but scornefull eyglaunce at him shot.
Was shot vp high, full of the stately tree,
To be auenged of that shot whyleare:
Vnto his Tygres taile, and shot at him apace.
Apace he shot, and yet he fled apace,
But the false Archer, which that arrow shot
And therewith shot an arrow at the lad;
Complayning, how with his empoysned shot
And march not past the mountenaunce of a shot.
With which he shot at randon, when him list,
And with a shaft was shot through either eye,
Well shot in yeares he seem'd, and rather bent
His foes haue slaine themselues, with whom he should contend.
Ah my deare Sonne (quoth he) how should, alas,
That should as death vnto my deare hart light:
To thinke that knighthood I so much should shame,
Through shield and bodie eke he should him beare:
How many mischieues should ensue his heedlesse hast.
In equall lists they should the morrow next it fight.
Had he not stouped so, he should haue clouen bee.
He standes amazed, how he thence should fade.
Where they should liue in woe, & die in wretchednesse.
Th'enchaunter vaine his errour should not rew:
And chauft, that any on his backe should sit;
That he my captiue langour should redeeme,
Else should this Redcrosse knight in bands haue dyde,
To see what end of fight should him befall that day.
Should die vnknown, & buried be in thanklesse thought.
As time in her iust terme the truth to light should bring.
As when iust time expired should appeare.
But he should die, who merites not to liue?
Till he should die his last, that is eternally.
That her to see should be but troublesome.
Indeede (quoth she) that should her trouble sore,
To lead aright, that he should neuer fall
All in his hand, euen dead we honour should.
And widowes ayd, least they should be vndone:
What end (quoth she) should cause vs take such paine,
Should make his marke, high heauen to attaine?
Should haue mine onely daughter to his Dame,
That day should faile me, ere I had them all declard.
Where it should not be quenched day nor night,
Why then should witlesse man so much misweene
Of other worldes he happily should heare?
Least his long way his aged limbes should tire:
That knight should knighthood euer so haue shent?
Or why should euer I henceforth desire,
How that same knight should do so foule amis,
Bynempt a sacred vow, which none should aye releace.
That as a law for euer should endure;
Else neuer should thy iudgement be so fraile,
Should need of all his armes, him to defend;
Yet feared least his boldnesse should offend,
And doubted, whether he himselfe should shew,
Is this to knight, that Ladie should againe
And therfore wisht me stay, till I more truth should fynd.
When I should see, that would me nearer moue,
That it should not deface all others lesser light?
Ne should faire Claribell with all her art,
She last should smart: with which cruell intent,
But whence should come that harme, which thou doest seeme
And shund the marke, at which it should be ment,
Should him dismay, and make him stoup so low,
That nothing should him hastily awake:
Whom should he, but his owne deare Lord, there see,
For feare least Force or Fraud should vnaware
Should be his pray. And therefore still on hye
O why should heauenly God to man haue such regard?
For why should a dead dog be deckt in armour bright?
What herce or steed (said he) should he haue dight,
In vaine therefore, Pyrrochles, should I lend
Why should not that dead carrion satisfie
His life for due reuenge should deare abie?
Wanting his sword, when he on foot should fight:
Great guerdon, well I wote, should you remaine,
If that your liues ye loue, as meete ye should;
So goodly workemanship should not endure:
Against the viaundes should be ministred.
And after wild, it should to her remaine:
Which they should hold of him, as subiect to Britayne.
And mightie deeds, should matched haue the best:
Yet should they be most famous moniments,
Which by the ransack of that peece they should attaine.
That him his foe more fiercely should pursew:
Least that his Lord they should behind inuade;
When the hart bloud should gush out of his chest,
Or his dead corse should fall vpon the flore;
Or shame, that euer should so fowle defects
Which by that new rencounter he should reare:
They stayd not to auise, who first should bee,
He should aduaunced be to high regard,
Of that great chamber, should be labour lost:
For feare least her vnwares she should abrayd,
Should euer enter in his bounteous thought,
(Said he) perhaps ye should it better find:
Of her miscarriage should in her be fond,
Least that it should her turne to foule repriefe,
Should of his dearest daughters hard misfortune heare.
For fear the cruell Feends should thee vnwares deuowre.
Certes I should be loth thee to molest:
Least backe againe the kingdome he from them should beare.
Should of her name and nation be chiefe,
For of a woman he should haue much ill,
A virgin strange and stout him should dismay, or kill.
That Proteus prophecide should him dismay,
To be hart-wounding loue, which should assay
Least they their finnes should bruze, and surbate sore
She should not then haue bene reliu'd againe,
Out of that forest should escape their might;
Through which he follow should his brethren bad,
That mortall men her glory should admire
Seemeth that such wild woods should far expell
Should happie be, and haue immortall blis:
She should aread; many resemblaunces
That I the same should faithfully fulfill,
And at the twelue monethes end should bring their names
To weet, that I my trauell should resume,
Ne euer to her presence should presume,
Her counsell, if he should her trust in me repose.
Should plonged be in such affliction,
And grudg'd to see the counterfet should shame
To turne his steede about, or sure he should be ded.
Then any should of falsenesse her reproue,
That euer hand should dare for to engore
This odious argument my rimes should shend,
But if it should not grieue you, backe agayne
And bad, that none their ioyous treason should reueale.
And home returne, where all should be renewd
And watcht, that none should enter nor issew;
Trembling through feare, least down he fallen should,
His owne deare mother, (ah why should he so?)
When that same Maske againe should forth arize.
He fell halfe dead; next stroke him should haue slaine,
Should be remedilesse, sith none but hee,
Yet should it be a pleasant tale, to tell
Lest she with blame her honor should attaint,
Should either winne him one, or lye without the dore.
But either he should neither of them haue, or both.
So none should be out shut, sith all of loues were fitted.
I saw, why should I doubt to tell the same?
Should equally be shard betwixt vs tway:
In doubt to whom she victorie should deeme,
That lost faire Ladies ornament should weare,
Assembled were, to weet whose she should bee,
They by consent should chose the stoutest three,
That with himselfe should combat for her sake,
And of them all the victour should his sister take.
And cared not to spare, that should be shortly spent.
And that he should not long on foote endure,
Whether of them in her should haue the greater share.
That she should surely beare the bell away,
And weend no mortall creature she should bee,
To whom each one his chalenge should disclame,
He should without disturbance her possesse:
In seeking him, that should her paine assoyle;
And bad him rise, or surely he should die.
Fearing least she your loues away should woo,
Which ended, then his bloudy banket should beginne.
Till time for him should remedy prouide,
And vow by Mahoune that he should be slaine.
Fearing least if she should him freely set,
Should wilfully be into thraldome brought,
Me seemes the gentle hart should most assured bind.
In case his burning lust should breake into excesse.
And in that right should by all knights be shielded:
Should happen this with liuing eye to see,
Wayting when as the Antheme should be sung on hye.
Should for the Gods in Proteus house be made;
Should fetch againe, and finally destroy
Why should they not likewise in loue agree,
That his departure thence should be so short,
That his decay should happen by a mayd.
For feare she should of lightnesse be detected:
And kept the crowne in which she should succeed.
If I should graunt that I haue doen the same,
But that I should die guiltie of the blame,
When as he saw she should be cut in twaine,
Did yield, she rather should with him remaine
And rather then his loue should suffer paine,
Should be solemniz'd: for if time he had,
Should meete, a trap was letten downe to fall
And otherwise, if that he should retire,
Else should afflicted wights oftimes despeire.
The third day came, that should due tryall lend
The honour of the prize should be adiudg'd by those.
And best to him, to whom the best should fall.
To whom that day they should the girlond yield.
And triall, whether should the honor get.
Then that his foe should him the field denie,
With whom a goodly doure I should haue got,
And should haue ioyned bene to her in wedlocks knot.
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
That what the sea vnto you sent, your own should seeme.
What other right (quoth he) should you esteeme,
That what the sea vnto you sent, your own should seeme.
That he of womens hands so base a death should dy.
She bad that streight the gates should be vnbard,
Vppon some fowle, that should her feast prepare;
Her to receiue, till time they should begin the fight.
That he thereon should spin both flax and tow;
What right is it, that he should thraldome find,
And, though (vnlike) they should for euer last,
I to your selfe should rest for euer bound,
Bereaue it thence: such blot his honour blemish should.
He should his purpose misse, which close he ment:
To thinke of your nights want, that should yee waking keepe.
Least any should betray his Lady treacherously.
That should their mindes vp to deuotion call,
All sodainely the bed, where she should lie,
Least any more such practise should proceede.
For her no other termes should euer tie
Like fruitles seede, of which vntimely death should grow.
And that they should for euer faithfull bee,
First, that sir Artegall should him array,
Should as his purchast prize with him conuay
He should his flale to finall execution bend.
To all, mongst whom this storie should be spoken,
And by which way they towards it should trace.
Were not (sayd she) that it should let your pace
Should issue forth, in hope to find some spoyle,
That should their powre against her right oppose.
Else should he thrise haue needed, for the nonce
To whether should the victory befall,
To loose the badge, that should his deedes display.
That none should dare him once to entertaine:
That vertue should be plentifully found,
Ere he doe come, he should be soone in place.
Well weend he streight, that he should be the same,
Or for a Ladie, whom a knight should loue,
The law of armes; yet breake it should againe,
He rather should haue taken vp behind.
To leaue his loue he should be ill apayd,
When forward we should fare, he flat refused
But should it not displease thee it to tell;
And lost the crowne, which should my head by right adorne.
Should weet of me, nor worke me any wrong.
I should no creature ioyne vnto mine ayde,
In stead of comfort, which we should embrace:
With thinking to what case her name should now be brought.
That should to me such curtesie afford,
That he should be so sterne to stranger wight:
Therefore misdoubting, least he should misguyde
Yet was it sayd, there should to him a sonne
Be gotten, not begotten, which should drinke
That from his sides some noble chyld should rize,
The which through fame should farre be magnifide,
And this proud gyant should with braue emprize
They should accomplish both a knightly deed,
Should issue forth, t'attach that scornefull lasse.
She wander should in companie of those,
As if it them should grieue to see his punishment.
And least he should recouer foote againe,
Disdaine and Scorne, I through the world should stray,
That so rich frute should be from vs bereft;
Which should befall to Calidores immortall name.
Should reap the haruest, ere it ripened were;
That Colin Clout should pipe as one most fit;
And Calidore should lead the ring, as hee
That he should lead the daunce, as was his fashion;
That he should neuer leaue, nor be delayd
That neuer more they should endure the shew
We should our selues demeane, to low, to hie;
That we likewise should mylde and gentle be,
That good should from vs goe, then come in greater store.
Where with such damned fiends she should in darknesse dwell.
The ioyes of loue, if they should euer last,
That he in time her ioyaunce should obtaine.
And willed streight the slaues should forth be called,
Bad them be still, his loue should not be sold:
Should with the rest be sold before him theare,
Least they should ioyne against the weaker side,
Or how faire Pastorell should haue bene sold
Vnto the place, to see what should be donne.
Should know thereof, to slay he would haue sought,
She should it cause be fostred vnder straunge attyre.
As through the world thereby should glorifie his name.
The stroke down fro[m]; her head vnto her shoulder glaunst.
As they the earth would shoulder from her seat,
Quite through his shield, and in his shoulder seasd,
He smote so manly on his shoulder plate,
And through his shoulder pierst; wherwith to grou[n]d
That from her shoulder to her heele downe raught,
Through Cambels shoulder it vnwarely went,
But by the shoulder him so sore he bit,
That he him maymed quite, and all his shoulder split.
And on her shoulder hung her shield, bedeckt
That glauncing on her shoulder plate, it bit
Strooke through his shoulder, that the blood ensew'd
He shouldered him from off the higher ground,
That on her shoulders sad a pot of water bore.
Disordred hong about his shoulders round,
With snowy lockes adowne his shoulders shed,
About her shoulders weren loosely shed,
Full large he was of limbe, and shoulders brode,
Vpon his shoulders carried him perforse
Now loose about her shoulders hong vndight,
That from his shoulders quite his head he reft:
And ouer all his shoulders did dispred,
And all about her necke and shoulders flew
Whose yuorie shoulders weren couered all,
To all about, and all her shoulders spred
And long curld locks, that downe his shoulders shagged,
His head meant from his shoulders to haue swept.
That had not grace thee blest, thou shouldest not suruiue.
And shouldred hath the Bull, which fayre Europa bore.
Some by close shouldring, some by flatteree;
Why shouldst thou then despeire, that chosen art?
But if thou now shouldst weigh them new in pound,
Is layd, they fiercely then begin to shoure,
With shoure and hayle so horrible and dred,
And poureth forth a sudden shoure of raine,
Some laught for sport, some did for wonder shout,
They all gan shout aloud, that all the heauen rings.
Gan shout aloud, that vnto heauen it rong;
And oft reioyce, and oft for wonder shout,
They shouted loud, and signes of gladnesse all did shew.
They shouted all for ioy of his successe,
Whereat they shouted all, and made a loud alarme.
Shouting, and clapping all their hands on hight,
Shouting, and singing all a shepheards ryme,
Confusd with womens cries, and shouts of boyes,
And perill without show: therefore your stroke
